content.description:
P1: WI3 climb a 20m curtain of ice, followed by a long snow slope.  Belay from a tree on the left 
  
 P2-3: WI3 climb the following ice curtain.  Belay from a tree on the right, or continue up left on an easier WI2 pitch 
  
 Descent: rap from tree or v-thread.  P1 can either be walked off or rapped from a tree anchor

From Panther Falls continue down the drainage on the right.  The falls will be on the left. It's visible from the trail heading to Panther Falls
tree anchors

This route lies less than 100 meters south of Bridalveil Falls. It starts in the gully just past a nice 8 meter curtain of ice that sometimes forms right into the creek. Plod up snow and rolling WI2 ice for 70 m to a tree belay on the left. Rap with double 70s to get to the ground.

Not worth it unless you've done both Bridalveil and Panther and are just bored and wanting some easy ice.

If anyone knows the actual name of this route or the FAs, please let me know.

Just past Bridalveil Falls in the obvious snow and ice gully.
Standard ice rack.

Panther Falls is an excellent route 1 or 2 pitch route with a very short approach. Not far from the Weeping Wall and Polar Circus just up the Icefields Parkway past the Big Bend. An excellent diversion if you have a bit of extra time. The route get's early sun. Mind the daggers on the left and right sides of the falls. The two most obvious lines are the left and right side, with the right side tending to be steeper, yet often more wet.

The two approaches are to walk the trail from the south end of the parking area heading downhill and left from the Bridal Veil Falls sign and tashcans. Alternatively, one can rap in from the top of the falls from a tree (2 raps). The climb is so close to the parking lot, so either way is quick although the approach trail has a bit of avy hazard. Although you can't see the climb at all till you approach it as the parking area is right above it, it's realitively quick to go check out. screws & v-threads

Panther Falls is an excellent single (long) pitch ice climb with at least two variations that regularly form.  Both go at about WI4. We climbed it in late April 2011 and it was really running with water on the right side while the left side was in decent shape.
